 <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc251391_16"></A>Summary Compensation Table </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and accompanying footnotes provide information regarding compensation earned, held by, or paid to, individuals holding the positions
of Chief (Principal) Executive Officer and Chief (Principal) Financial Officer during 2011 and the three most highly compensated of our other executive officers. We refer to these executive officers as our named executive officers. In accordance
with SEC rules, information is included for Mr.&nbsp;West who left the Company in June 2011. The following table provides information with respect to 2011, 2010 and 2009 compensation, if reported in our prior years&#146; proxy statements.
Ms.&nbsp;Buck and Mr.&nbsp;Walling were not named executive officers in the Company&#146;s 2011 or 2010 proxy statements; therefore, information on their 2010 or 2009 compensation is not included. </FONT></P>

 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">61 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;includes the aggregate grant date fair value of contingent target PSU awards for the 2011-2013 performance cycle and, with the exception of
Mr.&nbsp;Walling, for the 2011 adjusted earnings per share-diluted component of the 2010-2012 and 2009-2011 performance cycles. With the exception of Messrs.&nbsp;Bilbrey and Walling, Column&nbsp;(e) reflects the grant date fair value of the PSUs
awarded to each named executive officer in February&nbsp;2011. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s 2011 stock awards include the awards granted in February&nbsp;2011 and special PSU awards for the 2011-2013, 2010-2012 and 2009-2011 performance cycles granted
upon his promotion to CEO in May 2011. The amount listed in Column&nbsp;(e) for Mr.&nbsp;Walling includes contingent target units granted for the 2011-2013 performance cycle in June 2011 upon his hire. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

Annual Report to Stockholders that accompanies this proxy statement. The number and grant date fair value of stock options awarded to each named executive officer during 2011 appears in Columns&nbsp;(j)&nbsp;and (l)&nbsp;of the Grants of Plan-Based
Awards table. As a result of his termination, Mr.&nbsp;West forfeited all stock options awarded him in 2011 and unvested options awarded in prior years, which on the date of his termination of employment had a value of $7,502,156.

incentive program, which we refer to as the One Hershey Incentive Program, to the named executive officers for 2011. Awards under the One Hershey Incentive Program for 2011 are based on base salary received in 2011. Mr.&nbsp;West received no award
due to his resignation in the first half of 2011. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Column&nbsp;(h) reflects the aggregate change in the actuarial present value of the named executive officer&#146;s retirement benefit under the Company&#146;s
tax-qualified pension plan, the Compensation Limit Replacement Plan, or CLRP, and the Defined Benefit Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or DB&nbsp;SERP. The change in value calculation uses the same interest and mortality rate assumptions as
the 2011 audited financial statements and measures the change in value between the pension plan measurement date in the 2010 and 2011 audited financial statements. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">62 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">As a result of his resignation, Mr.&nbsp;West forfeited his entire DB&nbsp;SERP benefit. As of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2010, that amount was $6,162,105. In addition,
Mr.&nbsp;West received a distribution of his accrued benefit from the qualified defined benefit plan in the amount of $185,554. No further pension benefits are due to Mr.&nbsp;West as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Messrs.&nbsp;Alfonso, O&#146;Day and Walling participate in the DC&nbsp;SERP rather than the DB&nbsp;SERP. The DC&nbsp;SERP is authorized under the Company&#146;s
Deferred Compensation Plan. DC&nbsp;SERP contributions for Messrs.&nbsp;Alfonso, O&#146;Day and Walling are included in Column&nbsp;(i) as listed in footnote&nbsp;7 below. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:3%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The named executive officers also participate in our non-qualified, non-funded Deferred Compensation Plan under which deferred amounts are
credited with notional earnings based on the performance of one or more third-party investment options available to all participants in our 401(k). No portion of the notional earnings credited during 2011 was &#147;above market&#148; or
&#147;preferential.&#148; Consequently, no Deferred Compensation Plan earnings are included in amounts reported in Column&nbsp;(h)&nbsp;above. See the Pension Benefits and the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation tables for more information on the
benefits payable under the qualified pension plan, DB&nbsp;SERP, CLRP and Deferred Compensation Plan to the named executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(7)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">All other compensation includes 401(k) matching contributions, perquisites and other amounts as described below. Benefits based upon a percent of base salary are
computed as a percent of pay received in a calendar year. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

base salary up to the maximum amount permitted by the IRS. We call this contribution the Core Retirement Contribution. They also are eligible to receive a Supplemental Core Retirement Contribution of 3% of base salary in excess of the IRS limit.

officers are set forth in Column&nbsp;(g) of the Summary Compensation Table. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Grants of Plan-Based Awards </B></FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>

PSUs reflected in Columns&nbsp;(f),&nbsp;(g)&nbsp;and&nbsp;(h), RSUs listed in Column&nbsp;(i), and the stock options listed in Column&nbsp;(j). </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Except for Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey, Ms.&nbsp;Buck and Mr.&nbsp;Walling, the amounts shown in Columns&nbsp;(c),&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;and&nbsp;(e) represent the threshold, target and
maximum potential amounts that might have been payable based on the One Hershey Incentive Program targets approved for the named executive officers in February&nbsp;2011. For Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey, the amounts shown in
Columns&nbsp;(c),&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;and&nbsp;(e) represent the threshold, target and maximum potential amounts that might have been payable based on the One Hershey Incentive Program target amount approved in February&nbsp;2011 and the target amount
approved in May 2011, concurrent with his promotion to CEO. For Ms.&nbsp;Buck, the amounts shown in Columns&nbsp;(c), (d)&nbsp;and (e)&nbsp;represent the threshold, target and maximum potential amounts that might have been payable based on the One
Hershey Incentive Program target amount approved in February 2011 and the target amount approved in September 2011 upon Ms.&nbsp;Buck&#146;s promotion to Senior Vice President, Chief Growth Officer. For Mr.&nbsp;Walling, the amounts shown in
Columns&nbsp;(c), (d)&nbsp;and (e)&nbsp;represent the threshold, target and maximum potential amounts that might have been payable based on the One Hershey Incentive Program target approved in June 2011 upon his hire. All the amounts shown in
Columns&nbsp;(c), (d)&nbsp;and (e)&nbsp;are based upon pay received in 2011 and include the possible 30% adjustment to the financial scores. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The threshold amount is the amount that would have been payable had the minimum score been achieved. Target is the amount payable had the business and individual
performance scores been 100% on all metrics. The maximum amount reflects the highest amount payable for maximum scoring on all metrics. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

cycle and with the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Walling, for the 2011 adjusted earnings per&nbsp;share-diluted component of the 2010-2012 and the 2009-2011 performance cycles. For Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey, the number of units presented in Columns&nbsp;(f),
(g)&nbsp;and (h)&nbsp;includes PSUs awarded in February&nbsp;2011 and PSUs awarded upon his promotion to CEO in May&nbsp;2011. PSUs granted upon Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s promotion were: 13,950 units for the 2011-2013 performance cycle; 16,770 units
for the 2010-2012 performance cycle; and 6,520 units for the 2009-2011 performance cycle. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">65 </FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Three-year compound annual growth in adjusted earnings per&nbsp;share-diluted measured against an internal target (12.5% of the target award); and
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Annual growth in adjusted earnings per&nbsp;share-diluted measured against an internal target for each year of the three-year performance cycle (12.5%
of the target award per year). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Payment, if any, will be made in shares of the Company&#146;s Common Stock at the conclusion of the three-year performance cycle. The Committee will approve the targets
for the annual adjusted earnings per&nbsp;share-diluted metrics at the beginning of each of the three years in the performance cycle. The minimum award as shown in Column&nbsp;(f)&nbsp;is the number of shares payable for achievement of the threshold
level of performance on one of the metrics and the maximum award as shown in Column&nbsp;(h) is the number of shares payable for achievement of the maximum level of performance on all metrics. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

established for that performance cycle as disclosed in the Company&#146;s 2011 proxy statement. The number of PSUs earned for the 2009-2011 performance cycle was based upon results described in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis.

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The number of options awarded to each named executive officer on February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011, was targeted as one-half of the executive&#146;s long-term incentive
target percentage times his or her 2011 base salary divided by the Black-Scholes value of $9.95 for each option. The Black-Scholes value is based on the $51.42 exercise price for these options determined as the closing price on the New York Stock
Exchange of the Company&#146;s Common Stock on the award date, February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011. The actual number of options awarded varied from the target level based on the executive&#146;s performance evaluation for 2010. The options awarded to
Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey on May&nbsp;18,&nbsp;2011, and to Mr.&nbsp;Walling on June&nbsp;14,&nbsp;2011, had a Black-Scholes value of $10.30 and $10.32 for each option, respectively. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">All options awarded by the Company have a ten-year term and vest in 25% increments over four years. Unvested options are forfeited if the executive terminates his or
her employment, unless the termination is due to the executive&#146;s death, disability or retirement, in which case (i) options granted prior to April 28, 2011, continue to vest and are exercisable for five years following termination, and (ii)
options granted on or after April 28, 2011, vest immediately and are exercisable for five or three years (depending on the terms and conditions of the grant) following termination. Options granted in the year of retirement are prorated based upon
the number of full calendar months worked in that year. In the event of a change in control, options granted prior to April 28, 2011, automatically vest upon the change in control and options granted on or after April 28, 2011, automatically vest
unless a qualifying replacement award remains outstanding after the change in control, in which case options will vest in accordance with the original vesting schedule. Within the two-year period following a change in control, options will vest
immediately if the executive&#146;s employment is terminated without Cause or the executive resigns for Good Reason, as defined in the EBPP 3A. No option may be exercised later than the option expiration date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Columns&nbsp;(b) through&nbsp;(f) present information about stock options awarded to each named executive officer under the Incentive Plan. Each option
award vests in increments of 25% on each of the first four anniversaries of the grant date, subject to earlier vesting in the event of a change in control for awards granted prior to April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011. Awards granted
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">67 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">
on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, will vest earlier if a qualifying replacement award is not outstanding after the change in control. Generally, upon termination of employment, vested options
must be exercised and unvested options are cancelled, except in the case of retirement, death or disability in which case the options (i)&nbsp;continue to vest as scheduled (in the case of awards granted prior to April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011) or
(ii)&nbsp;vest immediately (in the case of awards granted on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011). Participants whose employment terminates due to retirement, death or disability may exercise vested options for up to five or three years (based on the
terms and conditions of the grant) after termination of employment. Options granted in the year of retirement are prorated based upon the number of full calendar months worked in that year. If termination occurs within two years after a change in
control for any reason other than for Cause or by the executive without Good Reason, any replacement awards relating to options granted on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, will vest in full and may be exercised for one year after termination. If
an executive officer is under age 55 and his or her employment is terminated for reasons other than for Cause or for Good Reason, the executive will be eligible to exercise all vested stock options and a prorated portion of his or her unvested stock
options held on the date of separation from service for a period of 120 days following separation. No option may be exercised after its expiration date. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Options listed in Column&nbsp;(b) are vested and may be exercised by the executive at any time subject to the terms of the stock option. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

options are scheduled to vest, subject to continued employment (or retirement, death or disability), prorating in the event of severance, and to possible acceleration in the event of a change in control. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>

on December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2011, the last trading day of 2011. Column&nbsp;(h) also includes accrued dividend equivalents through December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, on the RSUs included in Column&nbsp;(g). Accrued dividends will be paid in cash upon
vesting. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

exception of Mr.&nbsp;Walling, the second number in Column&nbsp;(i) is the maximum number of PSUs potentially payable for the 2010-2012 performance cycle. Based on progress to date against goals, amounts presented in Column&nbsp;(i) for both
performance cycles are at maximum, which is 250% of target. The actual number of PSUs earned, if any, will be determined at the end of each performance cycle and may be fewer than the number reflected in Column&nbsp;(i). </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&#151;</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:8px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000;width:21%">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The values shown in Column&nbsp;(b) represent the number of stock options exercised by the named executive officers during 2011, and Column&nbsp;(c) represents the
market value at the time of exercise of the shares purchased less the exercise price paid. Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s employment agreement provided him with a right to exercise any vested stock options for a period of 90 days following his separation.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">The values shown in Column&nbsp;(d) include the number of PSUs earned from the 2009-2011 performance cycle that ended on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, as determined by
the Committee, or, in the case of Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey, determined by the independent members of our Board. The results of the 2009-2011 performance cycle that ended on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, exceeded the financial targets established at the start
of the performance cycle. The awards included in Column&nbsp;(d) reflect payment at 192.75% of target. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey, Ms.&nbsp;Buck and Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Day elected to defer payment of their awards as described below. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso received
payment in Common Stock for his award in February&nbsp;2012. In accordance with the terms of the PSU award, each PSU represents one share of our Common Stock valued in Column&nbsp;(e) at $61.78, the closing price of our Common Stock on the New York
Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2011, the last trading day of 2011. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

described in more detail in the following footnotes. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey elected to defer a portion of the 36,088 shares payable to him from the 2009-2011 PSU cycle. The gross number of shares immediately payable to him,
10,449, was reduced by required tax withholdings, resulting in immediate distribution of 7,188 shares. The gross number of shares deferred, 25,639, was reduced by required tax withholdings, resulting in deferral of 25,081 shares. Based on
Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s deferral election, these 25,081 PSUs will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable taxes, upon his separation from service from the Company, subject to the requirements of section 409A of the IRC.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">On February&nbsp;17,&nbsp;2011, 625&nbsp;RSUs awarded to Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey in 2009 vested. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey elected to defer 100% of this award. On the vesting date of
these RSUs, Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey received a cash payment of $1,544, which was equivalent to dividends that would have been earned had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting period. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey utilized the net cash received after
taxes to meet tax obligations on the deferred portion of his award, resulting in deferral of all 625&nbsp;shares. Based on Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey&#146;s deferral election, these 625&nbsp;RSUs will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable
taxes, upon his separation from service from the Company, subject to the requirements of section 409A of the IRC. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

of the Company&#146;s Common Stock. In addition, Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey received a cash payment of $14,081, which was equivalent to dividends that would have been earned had he held Common Stock instead of RSUs during

the vesting period. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey utilized the net cash received after taxes and liquidated 1,545&nbsp;RSUs to meet tax obligations, resulting in his receipt of 2,205&nbsp;shares of the
Company&#146;s Common Stock. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

Ms.&nbsp;Buck received a cash payment of $2,997, which was equivalent to dividends that would have been earned had she held Common Stock instead of RSUs during the vesting period. Ms.&nbsp;Buck utilized the net cash received after taxes to meet tax

required tax withholdings, resulting in deferral of 18,074 shares. Based on Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Day&#146;s deferral election, these 18,074 PSUs will be paid as shares of Common Stock, net of applicable taxes, in January 2014. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc251391_20"></A>Pension Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of the named executive officers, with the exception of Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Day and Mr.&nbsp;Walling, is a participant in our tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and is fully vested in his or her
benefit under that plan. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey and Ms.&nbsp;Buck are eligible to participate in our non-qualified defined benefit Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, or DB&nbsp;SERP, as was Mr.&nbsp;West prior to his termination of employment. No
benefit is payable under the DB&nbsp;SERP if the executive officer terminates employment prior to age 55 or if he or she does not have five years of service with the Company. As of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey had attained age 55
with five years of service. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The combination of the tax-qualified and DB&nbsp;SERP plans was designed to provide a benefit on retirement at or
after reaching age 60 based on a joint and survivor annuity equal to 55% of final average compensation for an executive officer with 15 or more years of service (reduced pro rata for each year of service under 15). Effective
January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007, the benefit payable under the DB&nbsp;SERP to an executive officer who was age 50 or over as of January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007, was reduced by 10%, and the benefit payable to an executive officer who had not attained age 50 as
of January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007, was reduced by 20%. The benefit payable to Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey was reduced by 10% and the benefits payable to Ms.&nbsp;Buck and Mr.&nbsp;West were reduced by 20%. As a result of his termination, Mr.&nbsp;West forfeited his
DB SERP benefit. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Final average compensation is calculated as the sum of (i)&nbsp;the average of the highest three calendar years of base
salary paid over the last five years of employment with the Company and (ii)&nbsp;the average of the highest three annual incentive program awards for the last five years of employment with the Company, whether received or deferred. The benefit
accrued under the DB&nbsp;SERP is payable upon retirement in a lump sum, a life annuity with 50% benefit continuation to the participant&#146;s surviving spouse, or payment may be deferred in accordance with the provisions of the Company&#146;s
Deferred Compensation Plan. The lump sum is equal to the actuarial present value of the joint and survivor pension earned, reduced by the lump sum value of the benefits to be paid under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and the value of
the executive&#146;s Social Security benefits. If the executive officer terminates employment after age 55 but before age 60, the benefit is reduced for early retirement at a rate of 5%&nbsp;per year for the period until the executive would have
turned 60. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">70 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The CLRP provides eligible participants the defined benefit he or she would have earned under our
tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan were it not for the legal limitation on compensation used to determine benefits. An executive officer who is a participant in the DB&nbsp;SERP is not eligible to participate in the CLRP, unless he or she
(i)&nbsp;ceases to be designated by the Committee as eligible to participate in the DB&nbsp;SERP prior to his or her termination of employment with the Company or (ii)&nbsp;has his or her employment involuntarily terminated by the Company other than
for Cause prior to vesting in the DB&nbsp;SERP. Such executive officer would then become eligible to participate in the CLRP and to receive a benefit for all years in which he or she would have been a participant of the CLRP but for his or her
designation by the Committee to be eligible to participate in the DB&nbsp;SERP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive officers who are eligible for both the DC&nbsp;SERP
(described under Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation below) and the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan receive an additional credit under the CLRP equal to 3% of eligible earnings less the IRS annual limitation on compensation.
Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso is the only named executive officer eligible for the CLRP. Upon separation, benefits under the CLRP are payable in a single lump sum or may be deferred into the Deferred Compensation Plan. A participant is eligible for his or her
CLRP benefit upon separation from service (subject to the provisions of section 409A of the IRC) after five years of service or attaining age 55 (unless the participant is terminated for Cause). Payment is also made to the estate of a participant
who dies prior to separation from service. Participants who become disabled are 100% vested in their benefit and continue to accrue additional benefits for up to two additional years. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">71 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information regarding the present value of benefits
accrued under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan, as applicable, and the DB&nbsp;SERP or CLRP for each named executive officer as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. The amounts shown for the DB&nbsp;SERP reflect the reduction for the
present value of the benefits under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and Social Security benefits. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Pension
Benefits </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2011 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Tax-Qualified Defined Benefit</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">72 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc251391_21"></A>Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers are eligible to participate in The Hershey Company Deferred Compensation Plan. The Deferred Compensation Plan is a
non-qualified, non-funded plan that permits participants to defer compensation that would otherwise be payable to them currently. The Deferred Compensation Plan is intended to secure the goodwill and loyalty of participants by enabling them to defer
compensation when the participants deem it beneficial to do so and by providing a vehicle for the Company to provide, on a non-qualified basis, contributions which could not be made on the participants&#146; behalf to the tax-qualified 401(k). The
Company credits the Deferred Compensation Plan with a specified percentage of compensation for executive officers participating in the non-qualified DC&nbsp;SERP. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our named executive officers may elect to defer payments to be received from the DB&nbsp;SERP, DC&nbsp;SERP, CLRP, and the One Hershey Incentive Program as well as PSU and RSU awards, but not stock
options. Amounts deferred are credited to the participant&#146;s account under the Deferred Compensation Plan. Amounts deferred are fully vested and will be paid at a future date or at termination of employment, as elected by the participant.
DB&nbsp;SERP and CLRP payments designated for deferral into the Deferred Compensation Plan are not credited as earned but are credited in full upon the participant&#146;s retirement. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Payments are distributed in a lump sum or in annual installments for up to 15 years. All amounts are payable in a lump sum following a change in control. All elections and payments under the Deferred
Compensation Plan are subject to compliance with section 409A of the IRC which may limit elections and require a delay in payment of benefits in certain circumstances. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">While deferred, amounts are credited with notional earnings as if they were invested by the participant in one or more investment options available under the Deferred Compensation Plan. The investment
options under the Deferred Compensation Plan consist of investment in shares of our Common Stock or in mutual funds or other investments available to participants in our 401(k). The participants&#146; accounts under the Deferred Compensation Plan
will be adjusted daily, up or down, depending upon performance of the investment options elected. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007, we
began crediting the deferred compensation accounts of all employees, including the named executive officers, with the amount of employer matching contributions that exceed the limits established by the IRS for contribution to the 401(k). These
amounts are credited in the first quarter of the year after they are earned. As shown in the footnotes to the Summary Compensation Table beginning on page&nbsp;61, these amounts are designated as &#147;Supplemental 401(k) match&#148; and are
included as &#147;All Other Compensation&#148; in the year earned. These amounts also are included in Column&nbsp;(c) of the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation table in the year earned. All of the named executive officers are fully vested in the
Supplemental 401(k) match credits presented and will be paid at a future date or at termination of employment, as elected by the officer. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007, we began crediting the deferred compensation accounts of all employees hired on or after January&nbsp;1,&nbsp;2007,
including eligible named executive officers, with the amount of core retirement contributions that exceed the limits established by the IRS for contribution to the 401(k). These amounts are credited in the first quarter of the year after they are
earned. As shown in the footnotes to the Summary Compensation Table, these amounts are designated as &#147;Supplemental Core Retirement Contribution&#148; and are included as &#147;All Other Compensation&#148; in the year earned. These amounts also
are included in Column&nbsp;(c) of the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation table in the year earned. As of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Day was the only named executive officer eligible for the Supplemental Core Retirement
</FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">73 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
Contribution credit. He is fully vested in this benefit and will receive payment for this benefit at termination of employment subject to the provisions of section 409A of the IRC. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Messrs.&nbsp;Alfonso, O&#146;Day and Walling are eligible to participate in our DC&nbsp;SERP, a part of the Deferred Compensation Plan. The DC&nbsp;SERP
provides annual allocations to the Deferred Compensation Plan equal to a percentage of compensation determined by the Committee in its sole discretion. In order to receive the annual DC&nbsp;SERP allocation, an executive officer must (i)&nbsp;defer
in the 401(k) the maximum amount allowed by the Company or IRS and (ii)&nbsp;be employed on the last day of the plan year unless he or she terminates employment while at least age 55, retires, dies or becomes disabled. After completing five years of
service with the Company, an executive officer is vested in 10% increments based on his or her age. An executive age&nbsp;46 with five years of service is 10% vested and an executive age 55 with five years of service is 100% vested.
Messrs.&nbsp;Alfonso&#146;s,&nbsp;O&#146;Day&#146;s, and Walling&#146;s annual DC&nbsp;SERP allocation is equal to 12.5% of base salary and One Hershey Incentive Program award for the calendar year, whether paid or deferred. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso is 90%
vested in his DC SERP benefit. Messrs.&nbsp;O&#146;Day and&nbsp;Walling are not vested in any portion of their DC SERP benefit. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following
table sets forth information relating to the activity in the Deferred Compensation Plan accounts of the named executive officers during 2011 and the aggregate balance of the accounts as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>2011 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">D. J.
West</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&#151;</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><A NAME="toc251391_22"></A>Potential Payments Upon Termination or Change in Control </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We maintain plans covering our executive officers that will require us to provide incremental compensation in the event of involuntary termination of
employment or a change in control. We describe these obligations below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Overview </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We entered into an employment agreement with Mr.&nbsp;West at the time of his promotion to the position of President in October&nbsp;2007. The agreement
had a term of three years and renewed daily. The agreement contained provisions relating to his responsibilities, compensation, confidentiality, non-competition and non-solicitation commitments and agreements, and payments, if any, to be made to him
upon termination of employment. Our obligations under the agreement ended upon Mr.&nbsp;West&#146;s resignation and he was not entitled to, nor did he receive, any severance or other compensation under his employment agreement as a result of his
separation. This narrative does not include information on benefits the Company would pay or provide to Mr.&nbsp;West as he was no longer an employee of the Company on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey and our other named executive officers participate in the EBPP&nbsp;3A. The EBPP&nbsp;3A is intended to help us attract and retain
qualified executive employees and maintain a stable work environment by making a provision for the protection of covered executives in connection with a change in control of Hershey or termination of employment under certain circumstances.
</FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">75 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of our named executive officers was required to sign an Executive Confidentiality and Restrictive
Covenant Agreement, or ECRCA, as a condition to receiving long-term incentive compensation awards such as stock options and PSUs. The ECRCA obligates the executive officer to not disclose or misuse our confidential and proprietary information or,
for a period of 12 months following termination, carry on any activities that compete with our business. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Termination of employment and a
change in control also impact PSUs, RSUs and stock option awards we have made, as well as benefits payable under our employee benefit plans. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following narrative takes each termination of employment situation &#150; voluntary resignation, discharge for Cause, death, disability, retirement,
discharge without Cause, and resignation for Good Reason &#150; and a change in control of the Company, and describes the additional amounts, if any, that the Company would pay or provide to Messrs.&nbsp;Bilbrey, Alfonso, O&#146;Day and&nbsp;Walling
and Ms.&nbsp;Buck, or their beneficiaries as a result. The narrative below and the amounts shown reflect certain assumptions we have made in accordance with SEC rules. These assumptions are that the termination of employment or change in control
occurred on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, and that the value of a share of our Common Stock on that day was $61.78, the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange on December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2011, the last trading day of 2011. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, in keeping with SEC rules, the following narrative and amounts do not include payments and benefits which are not enhanced by the
termination of employment or change in control. These payments and benefits include: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Benefits accrued under the Company&#146;s broad-based, tax-qualified 401(k) and tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Accrued vacation pay, health plan continuation and other similar amounts payable when employment terminates under programs generally applicable to the
Company&#146;s salaried employees; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Supplemental 401(k) match provided to the named executive officers on the same basis as all other employees eligible for Supplemental 401(k) match;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Vested benefits accrued under the DB&nbsp;SERP and account balances held under the Deferred Compensation Plan as described above beginning on
pages&nbsp;70 and 73; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Stock options which have vested and become exercisable prior to termination of employment or change in control. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The payments and benefits described in the five bullet points above are referred to in the following discussion as the executive officer&#146;s
&#147;vested benefits.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Voluntary Resignation </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are not obligated to pay amounts over and above vested benefits to a named executive officer who voluntarily resigns. Vested stock options may not be exercised after the named executive officer&#146;s
resignation date unless the officer is age 55 or older, as described in Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability below. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge for Cause </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If we terminate a
named executive officer&#146;s employment for Cause, we are not obligated to pay the officer any amounts over and above the vested benefits. The named executive officer&#146;s right to exercise vested options expires upon discharge for Cause, and
amounts otherwise payable under the DB&nbsp;SERP are subject to forfeiture at the Company&#146;s discretion. In general, a discharge will be for Cause if the executive has intentionally failed to perform his or her duties or engaged in illegal
</FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">76 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
or gross misconduct that harms the Company. Effective in February&nbsp;2011, the EBPP&nbsp;3A was amended to provide that engaging in illegal conduct, gross negligence or willful misconduct,
material dishonesty or violation of Company policies, or bad faith actions not in the best interests of the Company will be grounds for discharge for Cause. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If an executive officer dies and has not met the vesting requirements
to be eligible to receive a benefit from the DB&nbsp;SERP, no benefits are paid. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey is fully vested in his DB&nbsp;SERP benefits as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A maximum monthly long-term disability benefit of $35,000 would be provided for Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey and $25,000 for all other named executive officers in the event of long-term disability. Long-term
disability benefits are payable until age 65. Long-term disability benefits are offset by other benefits such as Social Security. The maximum amount of the monthly long-term disability payments from all sources, assuming long-term disability on
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, is set forth in the tables below. The additional lump sum DB&nbsp;SERP amount that would be payable for Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey and Ms.&nbsp;Buck at age 65, attributable to vesting and benefit service credited during the
disability period for the DB&nbsp;SERP, if the executive&#146;s disability started on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, is shown on the table below. Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso participates in the CLRP which provides two additional years of credit after approval
for long-term disability benefits. Messrs.&nbsp;O&#146;Day and Walling are eligible for the Supplemental Core Retirement Contribution and would receive two additional years of Supplemental Core Retirement Contribution credit after approval for
long-term disability benefits. Messrs.&nbsp;Alfonso, O&#146;Day and Walling participate in the DC&nbsp;SERP which provides two additional years of credit after approval for long-term disability benefits. Those amounts are listed in the table below:
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:8px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000;width:21%">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects additional lump sum amount of DB&nbsp;SERP benefit payable at age 65 attributable to vesting and benefit service credited during the disability period.
</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects additional lump sum amount of CLRP benefit attributable to vesting and benefit service credited during the disability period. Also reflects two additional
years of DC&nbsp;SERP credit and full vesting upon disability. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects two additional years of Supplemental Core Retirement Contribution and DC&nbsp;SERP credit and full vesting upon disability. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of Stock Options upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Vested stock options remain exercisable for a period of five or three years (based on the provisions of the individual grant) following termination due to retirement after age 55, death or disability, but
not later than the option expiration date. Options awarded prior to April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, that are </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">77 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
not vested at the time of retirement, death or disability will continue to vest throughout the five-year period following retirement, death or disability according to the original vesting
schedule established at the grant date. Subsequent option awards in 2011 that are not vested at the time of retirement, death or disability will vest in full and the options will remain exercisable for a period of three years following termination.
Options granted in the year of retirement are prorated based upon the number of full calendar months worked in that year. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table
provides the number of unvested stock options as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, that would have become vested and remained exercisable during the five- or three-year periods following death or disability, or retirement, if applicable, on
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, and the value of those options based on the excess of the fair market value of our Common Stock on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, over the option exercise price. Messrs.&nbsp;Bilbrey and O&#146;Day were retirement eligible
on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Treatment of RSUs upon Retirement, Death or Disability </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Upon retirement any RSUs held by our named executive officers that are not vested are forfeited. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A prorated portion of unvested RSUs granted prior to April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, will vest upon death or disability. The prorated number of RSUs is based
upon the number of full and partial calendar months from the grant date to the date of death or disability divided by the full and partial calendar months from the grant date to the end of the restriction period, multiplied by the number of RSUs
originally granted. Unvested RSUs granted on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, will vest in full upon death or disability. The following table summarizes the unvested RSU awards that would have vested on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, if the
executive&#146;s employment terminated that day due to death or disability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="top" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-left:8px"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">K. R. Walling</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-LEFT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="BORDER-RIGHT:1px solid #000000; BORDER-BOTTOM:1px solid #000000; padding-right:8px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:8px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:2px;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000;width:21%">&nbsp;</P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Prorated number of unvested RSUs as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, for Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey. Mr.&nbsp;Walling&#146;s RSUs were granted in June 2011 and are not subject to
reduction upon death or disability. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Value of shares based on $61.78 closing price for our Common Stock on December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2011, the last trading day of 2011. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause; Resignation for Good Reason </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Under the EBPP&nbsp;3A, we have agreed to pay severance benefits of two times base salary paid in a lump sum if we terminate the executive officer&#146;s active employment without Cause (one and one-half
times base salary if the executive becomes a participant in EBPP&nbsp;3A after February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011). In addition, under the EBPP&nbsp;3A, we have agreed to provide a pro rata payment of the One Hershey Incentive Program award for the year in
which termination occurs. We also have agreed to provide, pursuant to the EBPP&nbsp;3A, additional severance payments in the amount which the executive officer would have been eligible to receive under the One Hershey Incentive Program for a period
of two years (18 months for participants first covered by EBPP&nbsp;3A after February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011) following termination. These benefits also are payable if the executive officer resigns from active employment for Good Reason. Good Reason
arises under the EBPP&nbsp;3A if we appoint a new Chief Executive Officer, and during the first two years of his or her tenure, the executive officer&#146;s position, authority, duties or responsibilities are diminished or base salary is reduced. If
an executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated for reasons other than for Cause or if the executive officer terminates for Good Reason, the Company will continue the executive&#146;s welfare benefits for a period of two years. Coverage for
disability and participation in all tax-qualified retirement plans will not be continued. For executives first covered by EBPP 3A after February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011, welfare benefit coverage will continue for 18 months. Mr.&nbsp;Walling is the only
named executive officer first covered by EBPP 3A after February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If an executive officer is under age 55 and his or her
employment is terminated for reasons other than for Cause, or if the executive officer terminates for Good Reason, the executive will be </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">79 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
eligible to exercise all vested stock options and a prorated portion of his or her unvested stock options held on the date of separation from service for a period of 120 days following
separation. If the executive officer is age 55 or older and his or her employment is terminated for reasons other than for Cause, or if the executive terminates for Good Reason, the executive will be entitled to exercise (provided any vesting
requirement has been satisfied as of the date of exercise) any outstanding stock options until the earlier of five or three years (based on the provisions of the individual grant) from the date of termination or the expiration of the options. In
addition, if an executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated for reasons other than for Cause, or if the executive officer terminates for Good Reason, the executive will receive payment for a prorated portion of any unvested RSUs held on the
date of separation from service. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table summarizes the amount of severance benefits that would be payable to the named executive
officer had his or her employment terminated on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, under circumstances entitling the officer to severance benefits as described above: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Special provisions apply if a change in control occurs. In general, a change in control will occur if the Milton Hershey School Trust no longer owns voting control of the Company and another person or
group acquires 30% or more of the combined voting power of our voting stock, there is an unwelcome change in a majority of the members of our Board, or, if after consummation of a merger or similar business transaction or a sale of substantially all
of our assets, the Milton Hershey School Trust does not own voting control of the merged or acquiring company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The EBPP&nbsp;3A provides the
vesting and payment of the following benefits upon a change in control to each of the named executive officers: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">To the extent not vested, full vesting of benefits under the tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan and the 401(k). </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Incentive Plan provides for full vesting of all outstanding stock options and RSUs (including accrued cash credits equivalent to dividends that would
have been earned had the executive held Common Stock instead of RSUs) granted prior to April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, upon a change in control. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The vesting and payment provisions applicable to PSUs, stock options and RSUs described above in the event of a change in control will not automatically
apply to awards made on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011. Under our Incentive Plan, if such awards are continued as a qualifying replacement award after the change in control, then no accelerated vesting or payment will occur because of the change
in control. In the event of termination of employment within two years following the change in control for any reason other than termination for Cause or resignation without Good Reason, the replacement award will vest and become payable as
described above. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following table and explanatory footnotes provide information with respect to the incremental amounts that would have
vested and become payable on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, if a change in control occurred on that date and any awards made on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, were continued as qualifying replacement awards: </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(1)</FONT></TD>

payable upon a change in control. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Reflects the value of unvested options that would vest upon a change in control based on the excess, if any, of the value of our Common Stock of $61.78 on
December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2011, the last trading day of 2011, over the exercise price for the options. Information regarding unvested options as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, can be found in the Outstanding Equity Awards table.

December&nbsp;30,&nbsp;2011, the last trading day of 2011. The accrued cash credits are equivalent to dividends that would have been earned had the executive held Common Stock instead of RSUs. Information regarding unvested RSUs as of
December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, can be found in the Outstanding Equity Awards table. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(5)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">Totals reflect full vesting of DB&nbsp;SERP and more favorable early retirement discount factors as provided under the EBPP&nbsp;3A. Mr.&nbsp;Bilbrey is fully vested in
his DB&nbsp;SERP benefit so no additional benefit is applicable. For Mr.&nbsp;Alfonso, the amount includes the vesting of his DC&nbsp;SERP benefit. For Ms.&nbsp;Buck, the amount includes the vesting of her DB&nbsp;SERP benefit. For
Mr.&nbsp;O&#146;Day, the amount includes the vesting of his DC&nbsp;SERP benefit. For Mr.&nbsp;Walling, the amount includes the vesting of his DC&nbsp;SERP and other non-vested retirement benefits. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">(6)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1">For any given executive, the total payments made in the event of termination after a change in control would be reduced to the &#147;safe harbor&#148; limit under IRC
section 280G if such reduction would result in a greater after-tax benefit for the executive. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Discharge Not for Cause or
Resignation for Good Reason after Change in Control </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">If the named executive officer&#146;s employment is terminated by the Company without
Cause or by the executive for Good Reason within two years after a change in control, we pay severance benefits to assist the executive in transitioning to new employment. Good Reason for this purpose means diminution of the executive&#146;s
position, authority, duties or responsibilities; a reduction in base salary; failure to pay current compensation or to continue in effect short- and long-term compensation and employee and retirement benefits; or the failure to fund a grantor trust
to support payment of amounts under the EBPP&nbsp;3A. The severance benefits under the EBPP&nbsp;3A for termination after a change in control as of December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011, consist of: </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A lump sum cash payment equal to two (or, if less, the number of full and fractional years from the date of termination to the executive&#146;s
65</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">th</SUP></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> birthday, but not less than one) times the
executive&#146;s base salary and the highest annual incentive program payment paid or payable during the three years preceding the year of the change in control (but not less than the annual incentive program target for the year of the change in
control); </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For replacement awards relating to awards granted on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, a cash payment equal to the PSU award for the performance cycle
ending in the year of the change in control at the greater of target or actual performance through the date of the change in control, with each PSU valued at the highest closing price for our Common Stock during the 60 days prior to the change in
control; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For replacement awards relating to awards granted on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, full vesting of outstanding PSU awards that are in the second
year of the performance cycle at the time of the change in control and prorating of outstanding PSU awards that are in the first year of the performance cycle at the time of the change in control; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

months), or payment of the value of such benefits if continuation is not permitted under the terms of the applicable plan; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:2px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">82 </FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For participants in the DB&nbsp;SERP an enhanced benefit reflecting an additional two years credit; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">For participants in the DC&nbsp;SERP an enhanced benefit reflecting a cash payment equal to the applicable percentage rate multiplied by his or her
annual base salary and last annual incentive pay calculated as if such amounts were paid during the years in the executive&#146;s severance period. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Until February&nbsp;22,&nbsp;2011, the EBPP&nbsp;3A also provided for a gross-up payment should the executive be subject to the excise tax on golden parachutes due to the receipt of severance benefits or
as a result of the payment or vesting of stock options upon the change in control. In February&nbsp;2011, we amended the EBPP&nbsp;3A to eliminate the excise tax gross-up for all participants. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Incentive Plan provides for full vesting of all unvested replacement awards relating to outstanding stock options and RSUs (including accrued cash
credits equivalent to dividends that would have been earned had the executive held Common Stock instead of RSUs) granted on or after April&nbsp;28,&nbsp;2011, for a termination after a change in control. The table below summarizes the severance
payments and all other amounts that would have vested and become payable if a change in control occurred and the executive&#146;s employment terminated on December&nbsp;31,&nbsp;2011. </FONT></P>
